projects.title: Arctic DP: Safe and Green Dynamic Positioning Operations of Offshore Vessels in an Arctic Environment
projects.description: The objective of this project is to enable future systems for DP in arctic environments to be automatic control systems. The control system must construct an accurate picture of the vessel’s and the environment’s situation, combining measurements with models in observers, and it must act on this information safely using automatic feedback control. However, in designing such control systems, it is vital to have a good understanding of the vessel and its hydrodynamics and the disturbances that influence the dynamic behavior of the vessel (ice; in addition to waves, wind and current). This means that focus is put on the DP vessel itself: ice-hull interaction forces and how to control the vessel for DP in ice, and on the ice management system: how to collect, analyze, and present ice data for the operation area and how to perform physical ice management.

projects.title: DYPIC: Dynamic Positioning in Ice
projects.description: Development of a tool box which allows the prediction of station keeping capability of different vessel types and offshore structures under various ice conditions.

contributors.headline: Company Owner bei Polar-Consult Dipl.-Ing. Peter Jochmann

projects.title: Deciphering of Ice Induced Vibrations
projects.description: The aim of this test program is to facilitate understanding of and quantify the phenomenon of frequency lock-in in the course of ice-induced vibration of offshore structures. The above-formulated aim will be reached by measuring the ice load on a harmonically vibrating vertical cylinder that is pulled through a uniform ice-sheet at a constant mean speed. The measured force will be decomposed to the frequency- and amplitude-dependent “added mass” and “added damping” by computing its in-phase with the acceleration and the in-phase with the velocity (both of the cylinder) components of the Fourier spectrum.

profile_positions.description:
Leading the Platform Engineering organization which consists of 5 departments:
1. Blockchains: extracting raw data from 12 different blockchains and making it available for downstream processing in various storage systems and databases
2. Attribution: contextualising the raw blockchain data by labelling high-value addresses using advanced data science techniques
3. Data Foundations: building the core data platform which serves all Nansen products
4. Site reliability engineering: ensuring stability and security of the cloud infrastructure that powers all Nansen products
5. Quality Assurance: ensuring quality of Nansen products though manual and automatic testing services
profile_positions.title: Director of Engineering

profile_positions.description: Co-founder and Chief Product & Technology Officer at Globus.ai, an AI-powered SaaS for recruitment. I was leading the entire engineering, product and design organisation. Grew the company from 4 to 50 people and helped ensure it's commercial success in Norway and internationally
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder & CPTO

profile_positions.description: Headshed Cube is a data-driven sales management software for call centers and sales departments. The products works on CRM data for outbound campaigns and enables real-time analysis, performance monitoring, segmentation and distribution of campaigns and individuals, powered by automated algorithms. I was a member of the Headshed Technical Advisory Board participating in strategic technological choices and product strategy
profile_positions.title: Member of the Technical Advisory Board

profile_positions.description: I was a Lead Data Scientist in a central team establishing the Digital Centre of Excellence in Statoil. Responsible for business analytics, preparation of executive briefs, developing business cases, hiring tech talent, managing external suppliers as well as managing technical deliveries to internal customers in projects comprising advanced analytics, data science, machine learning and artificial intelligence across the entire value chain: exploration and production, operations and maintenance, well delivery, project development, marketing, trading and supply chain management.
profile_positions.title: Lead Data Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Being a part of the Software Innovation team I was building predictive models and delivering analytical insights to the core business areas in Statoil:

- Machine learning framework for asset performance management and predictive maintenance. Predicting potential failures of heavy equipment and process optimization opportunities through data science
- An "Industrial Internet of Things" application for optimizing operations of seabed equipment across several assets. The project includes asset modeling, data ingestion, data storage and analytical insight delivery
- Predicting offshore logistics demand through integrated analytics of the supply chain
- Data analysis and interpretation software for optimized acquisition of ocean bottom seismic using predictive analytics
- Analyzing well data to improve well portfolio decisions for infill drilling
profile_positions.title: Senior Data Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Research and development project lead within Arcitc technology, focusing on software engineering and statistical data analysis:

- Developed a novel numerical environment for high-fidelity simulations of offshore operations in the Arctic – the Statoil’s SIBIS model
- Developed statistical methods for predicting ice loads on vessels and offshore structures in regions with benign ice conditions (Barents Sea, East Coast Canada)
- Developed novel sensors and instrumentation for ice data collection in the Arctic (ice load panels, optical ice acquisition methods, ice drift trackers)
- Contributed to Statoil's application for the 23rd licensing round on the Norwegian continental shelf (Barents Sea)
profile_positions.title: Senior Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Worked on research and development of novel engineering solutions for oil an gas industry operations in the Arctic:

- Developed and applied high-fidelity numerical models of ice-structure interaction
- Participated in design of offshore platforms for exploration and production in the Arctic (e.g. the Cat I drillship)
- Developed operational procedures for vessels in ice-covered waters (ice and iceberg management)
- Participated in ice model testing experiments at the Hamburg Ship Model Basin and Aker Arctic
- Participated in field data collection campaigns in the Arctic: Oden Arctic Technology Research Expeditions in 2012 and 2013
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description: I was serving on the Technical Committee of the ISO 19906 standard “Petroleum and natural gas industries - Arctic offshore structures” and contributing with expertise related to Ice Loads on offshore structures and Ice Engineering advisory in order to secure safe and sustainable development of the Arctic
profile_positions.title: Arctic Technology Expert

profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description:
I worked on 2 different projects at Intel:

- In 2008 I was developing statistical signal processing algorithms and simulation tools for indoor wireless communication systems and contributed to the IEEE 802.16 standard working group “Location Based Services for IEEE 802.16m, Relay Station Assistance”
- In 2009-2010 I was working in the High Performance Computing team, developing distributed packaging and installation solutions for the HPC family of Intel software development products (i.e. Intel Cluster Tools)
profile_positions.title: Software Engineering Intern

company.name: Institute of Applied Physics of Russian Academy of Sciences

profile_positions.company: Institute of Applied Physics of Russian Academy of Sciences
profile_positions.description: In my BSc research project in Fundamental Physics at the Department of Neurodynamics and Neurobiology I implemented a spiking neural network model in Matlab to study the polychronization phenomena, that is, reproducible time-locked but not synchronous firing patterns with millisecond precision, as in synfire braids. The network consisted of cortical spiking neurons with axonal conduction delays and spike-timing-dependent plasticity. The network exhibited sleeplike oscillations, gamma (40 Hz) rhythms, conversion of firing rates to spike timings, and other interesting regimes
profile_positions.title: BSc Researcher
